choices.text:
what are the verb tenses?
The past simple is used to describe actions that were completed in the past. The present perfect is often used with "have" or "has," and it describes an action taken up until now, combined with another action before a certain point of time (usually the present). For example: 
- I have lived here for five years ("I moved to this city 5 years ago"). This sentence uses both past simple tense. The first verb is in the past continuous form "lived," and it describes an ongoing event up until now, while the second one is a regular past simple action that also happened before present time: moving from another place (to here).
- I have finished my homework ("I started doing this task at 5 pm today"). This sentence uses both future perfect tense. The first verb "have" has an auxiliary form of "had," and it describes the completion or achievement in past, while second one is a regular present simple action that also happened before now: finishing something (homework).
- I have seen this movie twice ("I saw/watched... at 7 pm yesterday"). This sentence uses both perfect tense. The first verb has an auxiliary form of "have," and it describes the completion or achievement in past, while second one is a regular present simple action that also happened before now: seeing something (the same thing).
